private_information: I can only interact with vowel-labeled blocks (A, E, I).
I may only pick the top block of any stack and move exactly one block at a time.
I can place a block either on the table or on top of another block if that block is currently exposed (top of its stack).
vowel_agent.goal: Help transform the initial stacks into the global target stacking order by manipulating vowel blocks when allowed.

private_information: I can only interact with consonant-labeled blocks (B, C, D, F, G, H, J).
I may only pick the top block of any stack and move exactly one block at a time.
I can place a block either on the table or on top of another block if that block is currently exposed (top of its stack).
consonant_agent.goal: Help transform the initial stacks into the global target stacking order by manipulating consonant blocks when allowed.

private_information: I coordinate the two agents and integrate their partial plans or move suggestions.
I am responsible for producing the final PDDL domain and problem for the FastDownward solver.
orchestrator.goal: Produce a combined PDDL domain and PDDL problem that encodes the block manipulation task and is compatible with the FastDownward planner.

init.access_rule: Agents can only access top blocks of stacks and move one block at a time.

public_information: There are 10 uniquely labeled blocks: G, E, F, J, C, H, A, I, B, D.
Initial stacks on the table are as follows: Stack1 from bottom to top is G, F, J, C, H, D. Stack2 from bottom to top is E, A, I, B.

All stacks rest on the table. An agent may pick only the top block of any stack and may place that block either directly on the table or on top of another stack's top block, respecting its access permissions.
The global goal is to produce a single stack where, from top to bottom, the blocks are A on B, B on C, C on D, D on E, E on F, F on G, G on H, H on I, I on J, and J on the table.

pddl.system_prompt: You are an agent expert in performing block moves for vowel-labeled blocks. You may only move topmost vowel blocks and can move exactly one block at a time.
pddl.prompt: Your name is vowel_agent. You are given the public environment description and your private capabilities. Consider the initial stacking configuration and the global goal. Provide a clear, ordered list of valid concrete moves that only involve vowel blocks (A, E, I). Each move should be described in the form pick(block, from) then place(block, to) using object names. Do not emit PDDL. Focus only on moves you are able to perform given your constraints.

pddl.system_prompt: You are an agent expert in performing block moves for consonant-labeled blocks. You may only move topmost consonant blocks and can move exactly one block at a time.
pddl.prompt: Your name is consonant_agent. You are given the public environment description and your private capabilities. Consider the initial stacking configuration and the global goal. Provide a clear, ordered list of valid concrete moves that only involve consonant blocks (B, C, D, F, G, H, J). Each move should be described in the form pick(block, from) then place(block, to) using object names. Do not emit PDDL. Focus only on moves you are able to perform given your constraints.

pddl.system_prompt: You are an expert with multi-agent PDDL problems. You must produce a PDDL domain and a PDDL problem compatible with the FastDownward planner. Keep agent actions distinct in the domain so moves by vowel_agent and consonant_agent are identifiable.
pddl.prompt: You are the orchestrator. Integrate the public environment information and the concrete move suggestions produced by the two agents to produce a single coherent planning specification suitable for FastDownward. The PDDL domain must encode two distinct action schemas or action names reflecting the permissions of the two agents (for example, vowel_move and consonant_move), with preconditions that restrict which blocks each agent may move. The domain must model the standard blocksworld predicates such as on, ontable, clear, and handempty as needed. The PDDL problem must encode the initial state exactly as given and the goal stacking exactly as given. Provide the PDDL domain enclosed between <domain></domain> tags and the PDDL problem enclosed between <problem></problem> tags. Ensure the output is ready to be consumed by FastDownward and that agent-specific actions remain distinct.
